title: 111_hr3133
content: The Act may be cited as the "Foreign Evidence Request Efficiency Act of 2009" and includes improvements to Title 18. Title 18 of the United States Code is amended to change procedures for court jurisdiction in various subsections. Title 18 of the United States Code is amended to change procedures for court jurisdiction, including district courts of the United States, United States courts of appeals, and state courts with criminal jurisdiction. The amendment to Title 18 of the United States Code includes changes to court jurisdiction procedures, such as the authorization of state search warrants and the execution of foreign requests for assistance in criminal investigations and prosecutions. The amendment to Title 18 of the United States Code allows Federal judges to issue orders to assist foreign authorities in criminal investigations and prosecutions, including search warrants and orders for electronic communications. The amendment to Title 18 of the United States Code allows Federal judges to issue orders for pen registers, trap and trace devices, testimony, statements, and document production in response to requests from foreign authorities. Appointed persons can direct the taking of testimony, issue orders for appearance or document production, and administer oaths. The amendment to Title 18 of the United States Code allows Federal judges to issue orders for pen registers, trap and trace devices, testimony, statements, and document production in response to requests from foreign authorities. Appointed persons can administer oaths, take testimony, and receive documents or other things. Requests can be filed in the district where the person resides, where documents are located, or where a related Federal criminal investigation is being conducted. An application for a search warrant from a foreign authority under this section is subject to limitations. A Federal judge may issue a search warrant under this section only if the foreign offense involves conduct punishable by imprisonment for more than one year. Orders or warrants issued can be served anywhere in the United States. Foreign authorities or interested persons can seek assistance in criminal investigations under section 1782 of title 28, United States Code. Definitions for "Federal judge" and "attorney for the Government" are provided in this section. The term 'foreign authority' refers to a foreign judicial authority or an authority designated for requesting assistance in criminal matters. Foreign requests for assistance in criminal investigations and prosecutions.
